is in the mood. Last night, she came up on the couch with me and I 
scratched her face. Then she fell asleep next to me. She is afraid of

top_comment.text:
questions about my cat .
1.my cat stay awake in night and sleeps the whole day.
2.my cat is a street cat and he is a cute cat i adopted him.
3.when i touch his belly he scratches me or bite me softly.
4.should i feed meat and rice or use cat food.
5.he is scared when he see's a new person.
6.he is scared of a ball.
7.he pee on the litter box and poops beside a tree.
8.my litter box is round.
9.beside my house there is a big fat street when he is out for a while to 
walk the fat cat hits and tries to  kills him one day the fat cat scratched 
him and blood came from his nose.
10. he is nearly 1 year old.﻿
top_comment.author: Mohd Akmal

comments.text:
+Mohd Akmal I might be a bit late on the answer but I can try to answer 
your questions. 




1. Cats are nocturnal animals, they hunt during the night and sleep during 
the day, that's nothing special just nature.
2. I don't entirely understand this question, since its more a fact about 
the cat then its a question. 
3. The belly is an area the cat is really protective over, its the most 
vulnerable place on the body so it is afraid that someone could attack him 
there. Just don't touch the cats belly since most cats don't like that.
4. You should just feed him things cat normally eat, give him cat food and 
maybe some Tuna every now and then. Its not dangerous if it eats something 
like bread and things like that but try to refrain from giving it food that 
they normally wouldn't eat if they lived in the wild. (except for cat food) 
P.S Never give them milk. 
5. He/she might be a bit insecure meting new people since he/she doesn't 
know who they are and if they could possibly be a threat, I would recommend 
that the people coming to visit sits down and let the cat come to them if 
he/she wants to meet them. 
6. Balls can be fast objects and can hurt if they are hit by it, he/she 
might be scared that the ball might injure him/her if it goes with high 
speed towards him/her so just don't use balls as toys. 
7. Keep litter boxes in areas you might spend a lot of time, you never know 
if the cat might pee on something because he/she wants to mingle his smell 
with yours, also make sure you have places high up so he/she can be to look 
down on things, since the cat prefers being high up. 
8. Unless the litter box is closed off and its like a room then the shape 
shouldn't be a problem, make sure that its an open litter box and not a 
little room. 
9. Cats are territorial creatures, so if there are cats in the area they 
will probably fight since they fight over who is the owner of the 
territory. The other cat wont kill your cat, that is highly unlikely and if 
the cat is older then yours its most likely that its stronger and that is 
why your cat can't really do anything against it. Just make sure that if 
something serious happens that you notify the owners of the other cat and 
that you take your cat to a vet. 
10. Not really a question like number 2, its more of a fact about your cat.
comments.author: Solitude Guard

comments.text:

but he gets up and does other things in the morning to

comments.author: Helene Theodorsen

top_comment.text:
Hi Jackson! Could you give us any tips on how to play with two cats? I 
noticed when I try to engage with my cats, they tend to be very wary of 
each other, and get spooked if they pursue the toy at the same time. In the 
end one will continue to play, while the other will walk away and just 
observe from a distance :( Is this because cats have some "play etiquette" 
that I don't understand? Would appreciate your advice. ﻿
top_comment.author: Azjatycki Cukier

comments.text:
I have 2 cats and deal with this daily.  I tied a toy on heavy string for 
each cat.  I keep one string in each hand and keep each cat on either side 
of me for most of the playing.  I'll also walk down the hall trailing both 
toys behind me and they come racing behind me and forget that they're both 
together. I've gotten pretty good at keeping them both entertained at the 
same time.  I think it's more about safe territory for each cat so I 
provide that as best I can.  The love to play and they're not shy about 
asking for play time either!
comments.author: Zoe Skyflyer

comments.text:
+Yhoni Young
 Thank you for the advice Yhonj :D Maybe I should do more structured turns 
or try the double toy approach.
comments.author: Azjatycki Cukier

comments.text:
My cats do this.  Depending on the game I can get them to take turns (it 
helps that one of them has a natural understanding of this concept).  I 
play with one until she's exhausted, then the other cat takes over.  Cats 
have short top energy spans so have a little breather every ten minutes or 
so, works well for them.  I verbally engage the observer to let him/her 
know it's their turn next.  If one cat really doesn't want to share, I take 
two toys.  Both cats have different favourite toys, so that helps.  
Sometimes they make etiguette mistakes, both jump out at the same time, but 
it doesn't end up in a fight.  Hope this helps you. (Oh, none of the above 
works when trying to walk two cats on leads at the same time!!!)
comments.author: Yhoni Young

top_comment.text:
My cat is over a year old, and she is kind of a cross between mojito cat 
and wallflower cat. When i got her She was 3 months and it took her a while 
to open up to me. Many of my visitors don't know that i have a cat because

runs when you walk towards her, and she comes to you when she wants to, not 
right when you call her unless you have treats or food. She attacks my 
partner's legs all night and plays all night, but when I'm home she's quiet 
when it's late MOST of the time. Any insight on who she is??﻿

comments.text:

declawed our next two cats so our original cat wouldn't be unsafe 
living with non-declawed cats. I think it's pretty horrible to declaw cats 
but if you have to, you have to.
comments.author: Nicole Erin

comments.text: +Blu Evo made me laugh so hard. Props to you
comments.author: Aliyaaah1805

comments.text:
When I moved into my current house, the property manager wanted to know if 
my cats were fixed and declawed. I answered that my cats were all fixed. It 
limits my renting options to have cats, and limits my options *more* 
because my cats aren't declawed.  Apparently, there are cat owners letting 
their cats tear up rental property. Regardless, when a friend asked me how 
much it costs to have a cat declawed I answered in my most ominous voice "A 
piece of your soul".
comments.author: Blu Evo

comments.text:
+Danielle Baldridge good points. I don't think it is the responsibility of 
activists to try and belittle or destroy people who have declawed cats out 
of ignorance or social norms. What's done is done. The job is to educate 
and prevent further declawing, plain and simple.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
In America, declawing seemed a lot more popular about 20 years ago. When I 
was growing up we declawed our cats and it was quite common. No one really 
knew what it was like they do now. One girl was a year old after we spayed 
and declawed her and she was never the same (her paws also got infected 
after the procedure) anyway, it seems that people are becoming more aware 
of the realities of declawing. When I told my parents (who had originally 
declawed our childhood cats) that I wasn't declawing my two, she said "good 
for you" there is still a lot of ignorance about this topic but it seems 
most cat owning Americans are starting to realize just how bad it really 
is. I hope it never becomes a thing in the UK. Hopefully you learned from 
our mistake. (it became so ingrained in our culture it's still hard to 
remove it completely)
comments.author: Danielle Baldridge

comments.text:
Many people are ignorant about it. When I first brought up the subject of 
having a cat, my (not really educated about animals at all) dad agreed. I 
thought we were fine, until I mentioned buying a scratching post, to which 
he was confused about. "Why would we need a scratching post? Aren't you 
going to declaw it?" The next day, he nearly lost part of his thumb in an 
accident involving a lawn mower. Karma, b*tch. (I did end up getting a cat, 
but we never declawed her. I explained how the operation actually is a form 
of amputation, and my dad never brought the subject up again).
comments.author: Echo8081

comments.text:
i think lots of people don't know what it actually does to the cat. the 
vets saying that it's good and everyone should do it doesn't help
comments.author: borderpatrol8D

comments.text:
I have my 2 cats declawed only on the front paws. To be honest, I had this 
done before knowing how it relates to a person having their fingers removed 
up to the first knuckle. Not to mention that it was very common for people 
to have this done to their cats without causing issues. I never had issues 
with my cats after doing this and they behave no differently. However, 
whenever I get a new cat, I will look into other options, ie. trimming, 
nail caps, etc.
comments.author: Trina Bolton

comments.text:
+Clete Kass that sign is from the documentary "the paw project" if you have 
Netflix you can stream it
comments.author: ShockingWizard 26

comments.text:
There's a recent news article that was released about these owners who 
abandoned their and when someone found him all four of his paws were 
declawed and his teeth were filled down. Why would a vet ever agree to 
doing that?
comments.author: Kat

comments.text:
I know I watched a documentary about it and I instantly started feeling bad 
and mad about people who declaw their cats and the doctors that do those 
poor cats
comments.author: ShockingWizard 26

comments.text:
Last but not least, if you take a glance at the sign again, it will show a 
human hand missing the last knuckle on each finger.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
It has also become a big cash staple in the vet field. Thousands of 
americans get it done to their kittens every single day, and the vets are 
trained in school that it is good so they don't feel bad recommending and 
performing it.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
Because they don't want the cat to scratch them or their things and do not 
want to train them not to. I personally find it pretty messed up.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text: like Kitty Softpaws from Puss in Boots ?
comments.author: Aisya Hobo

comments.text:
We got my cat declawed, only her front ones just so she wouldn't scratch me 
or my sister. I was really little at the time when we got her, it was not 
cause we wanted to torture her.
comments.author: Lauren Sylar

top_comment.text:
I have a mojito cat that I picked up as a kitten named Yoris. He was 
abandoned outside. He loves people, and is not fixed. Yet he still pees on 
everything. I even got multiple litter boxes scattered around the house. 
Should I get more litter boxes? or does he might have a urinal problem? Or 
get him fixed for sure?

 I have two other cats as well Sakura ( fixed female) and Noctis (Fixed 
male), both are fine and happy. They don't mind Yoris at all, and will even 
play with him. Though sometimes I think they just tolerate them, since my 
other cats are pretty docile. Sometimes they push each other out of the cat 
beds, or share them. They are big enough for two cats each. I have them in 
several rooms in the house. They do that just to be in the same room I am. 
Should I get more cat beds or perches? ﻿
top_comment.author: 夏目春香

comments.text: Fix him.

Any unfixed cat will spray and mark their territory until they are fixed. I

comments.text: I have a mojito cat called Boris xD

top_comment.text:
Hi, my cat susu is almost 1 year old now, she gave birth to 5 kittens but 
they were premature and too weak so they died one after another.. Susu 
didn't seem to be bothered with this until her last kitten died.. she went 
crazy running around the house and meowing and talking to everyone in the 
house and carrying her dead kitten from one place to another.. she finally 
let me take the kitten away.. then seemed to forgotten about him but she 
wants to be petted ALL the time. She follows me everywhere and meowing and 
i dont understand her she just wants to be petted so what is going on?﻿
top_comment.author: Raneem Abdelhadi

comments.text:
Yeah, the stories of mother cats going crazy over dead kittens really 
breaks my heart.
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
Same thing happened with my cat, she had two kittens the first died but the 
second lived, she is meowing and looking for her lost kitten, so if she

attention, I meow back and she usually replies, I don't speak cat so idk 
what I say in cal language
comments.author: -Catsrock237 -

comments.text:
We have 3 Mojito girls. Friendly, talkative outgoing. Two adult desexed 
females and one baby girl cat ( still being intragrated with Ruby and

love watching them.
comments.author: Trish Mason

comments.text: she is mourning
comments.author: Clete Kass

comments.text:
Poor thing. Thank you so much for your time. I will get her fixed soon if

comments.author: Raneem Abdelhadi

comments.text:
once a mother cat has the litter, she is suppose to spend next 10 - 12 wks 
caring for her kittens. Now your cat's kittens all died prematurely, and 
she is still in the maternity mode, it may explains why she is following 
you around. Many cats think of their owners as their family members, that's 
why they bring home their kills as their way of saying they're trying to 
take care of you. There are many examples of cats whom had lost their 
litters prematurely, and ended up being seregate mothers to other species 
of animals such as puppies.  Now back to your cat su su, her situation will 
remedy it self with time, once her natural needs to care for her  kittens 
wear off. In the mean time, try to spend more time with her, It may bond 
you and her closer. Get her fixed will also help. Plus if you don't get her 
fixed soon, she is going to have another litter of kittens.
comments.author: David Lee

comments.text:

comments.author: Miner Kitten

top_comment.text:
My cat, Jäger, is kind of a mix of all three. Everywhere around the house, 
she's a Mojito cat and she gets along well with my dog and other people 
most of the time. When I got her, it was a suprise, and when I went 
downstairs to see her, she was perfectly fine with me and started rubbing 
her face on everything.
She's a Napoleon-ish cat when she's in the bathroom. Whenever I go in 
there. She immediately runs after me most of the time and stays there until 
I leave. (Maybe because I put her food in there along with her litter box 
and she's trying to protect it. Or because she just likes to see the toilet 
flush. XD)
She's a Wallflower cat when my dog goes full-on attack mode though. No, not 
trying to eat her (although he has kind of swallowed her head. He never 
bites down though.), he's playing with her. But she gets a little scared 
and quickly runs under the bed and hides~.

(Also no, I didn't name my cat Jäger after the liquor, but because it means 
Hunter in German. And wow, does she like to hunt small plastic things for 
some reason....)﻿
top_comment.author: Kєndαll “Arυmíηαtí” Sιℓνєя

to hug the walls.

comments.text:

well, I'll be subscribing!. Perhaps we'll get some answers....?

captions.text:
Live from the cat
cave in downtown God

knows where next to the
washer and the dryer,

it's Cat Mojo with
Jackson Galaxy.
Welcome, welcome to Cat Mojo.

I'm Jackson Galaxy
live from the cat cave.

It is actually looking more like
a cave these days, isn't it?

There's all kinds
of fun stuff here.
I wanted to point this out.

Diane Dial in Florida,
thank you, Diane,

for sending this
picture, this painting,
of my lovely cat Caroline.

Don't you see the
resemblance, Caroline?

It will become a permanent
fixture in the cat cave.
Let's talk about Cat Mojo 101.
What is cat mojo?

We've talked about this
before, but let's bring up

that little dictionary
looking thing.

It says cat mojo, what
motivates all cats.
It's very simple.

The fact is that it wasn't
until about 120 years ago

that we permanently brought
cats into our houses.

And that means that they
live a very pure existence.

They still have it hardwired
in their brain to hunt.

And that is the first
thing about cat mojo,
hunt, catch, kill, eat.

What's the second thing that's
so important about cat mojo?
What motivates them?

Well, with the hunting, and
the catching, and the killing,

and the eating comes
the owning, right?
It's all about ownership.

Cats need to own
their territory.

If they don't own
their territory,

bad things will happen
to them or to you.

So first we have
the confident owner

of territory, the one
who walks in chest

held high, tail in
that backwards question

mark, everything
relaxed, comes up to you,

gives you a little
head butt, weaving

in and out of your legs,
blinky eyes at you,

that kind of thing,
very confident.
Now, who is that cat?

If they were a person,
you would come in

at a party, a cocktail
party, knocking at the door.

They open the door
with a tray of mojitos.

And would you like
one of these mojitos?

Cucumber, a little bit
of cucumber in here,

I thought you'd
like that very much.
Welcome to my house.
Don't you love it very much?
Come on.
I'll give you a tour.

Mojito cat, that's
who mojito cat is.

Number two, Napoleon
cat, aka the over-owner,
who is that cat?

The chest out, a little bit
of the ears forward glaring

at you a little
bit, eyes zeroing

in on you just a
little, going down

in that offensive,
aggressive posture,

perhaps laying down across
the doorway of the house

to make sure you've
got to step over
that line, peeing on things.

Yes, peeing, because
they don't trust

their ownership
of the territory.

All whether they're
people or animals who

don't trust their
territory over-own, right?

Hence Napoleon, or sort
of a gang mentality.
You see the writing on the wall?
I own this.

Why does that come
out like that?
Why you puff up like that?

You do that, man, because
you are not confident
that you own the joint.
So you over-own.
That is Napoleon Cat.

Number three, that
would be the wallflower.

In cat world, the wallflower
literally hugs the wall.

In the meantime, the
over-owner laying

across the doorway, the mojito
cat just walking around,
hey, how you doing?

Then you've got The Wallflower
hanging back against the wall,

never walking across
the middle of the floor.
That would never happen.

In the meantime, they are
going, I don't own this.
You, you, you're the owner?

Fine, fine, I'm
not looking at you.
I'm not looking.

I'm just going to the
litter box over there.
I'm just leaving, goodbye.
That's the wallflower.

Now, I want all cats
to be the mojito cat.
That's what I strive for.

If they are the over-owner,
if they are the wallflower,
we got problems.

Cat Mojo 101, your
homework assignment
is take a look at your cat.
Watch them walk into a room.

Watch them interact with
other cats and other humans.

And figure out who they
are, who they resemble.

If they're a
wallflower, we've got
to bring them out a little bit.

If they're an
over-owner, we've got
to bring them back a little bit.
Why?

Because we want everyone
to be the mojito cat.

That is the quest, the
quest for the mojito cat.

That's what we're
getting at here.
But figure out who your cat is.

Watch him walk around the
joint, because that's the thing.

Do they display confident
ownership of territory?

Are you encouraging your
cat to hunt, catch, kill,

and eat through play
every single day?

Are you feeling them a
bio-appropriate diet?

Because that will
also feed in- ha ha

no pun intended-- to that
healthy lifestyle of every cat.

That's what you want
to be looking at.

Until next time, do
take a look at all

of these different places
you can hook up with me.
Please subscribe.

You'll get all kinds of
mojo-licious news coming up

really soon,
including giveaways,
Google Hangouts live.

I can answer questions
for you guys,

tell you what's coming up in
the world of the cat cave.

And speaking of
Google Hangouts, be

sure to join me on
Wednesday, February 5.

I'll answer your
questions, and we're

going to talk more
about declawing.

So stay tuned for
more information.

But, man, get that on your
calendar and do it now.
Hey, I hope that helped.

I hope you get the
concept of cat mojo
even more so than before.
Take a look at your cats.

Remember every cat is an
individual, just like people

and snowflakes, except there
is a place where we all start.

And that's an important
thing to figure out, OK?

Until next we meet, folks,
all light, all love, all mojo.
Love you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
